messageBody:
On 11/29/06, Michael Feathers <mfeathers@...> wrote:
>
>
> With more realistic examples, it's nicer. When you use the try/catch
> form you can move some of your action code above the try. The problem
> with the annotation solution is that it doesn't point out the call that
> is supposed to throw the exception: it could be any call in the test
> method.


True, but in practice, what is the likelihood that in the same test method,
you have several calls that can throw the same exception and that during
your test run, it's the wrong one that throws it?

It's pretty unlikely in my experience, especially if you are writing unit
tests which, by definition, should have minimal bodies of code.

At any rate, the annotation approach is really a 90/10 kind of situation:
it addresses in a concise and readable form 90% of your exception tests and
still lets you revert to the older way of testing if your needs fall in the
other 10%.
